description.summary: One-eyed giants from Greek mythology. Two distinct traditions exist: savage shepherds (Homeric) and divine craftsmen who forged Zeus' thunderbolts (Hesiodic).
description.full: The Cyclopes (singular: Cyclops) are one-eyed giants from Greek mythology, characterized by a single large eye in the center of their forehead and enormous size and strength. Two distinct mythological traditions exist: the Homeric Cyclopes are lawless, savage shepherds dwelling in caves and eating human flesh, most famously Polyphemus who was blinded by Odysseus; the Hesiodic Cyclopes (Brontes, Steropes, and Arges) are divine craftsmen, sons of Uranus and Gaia, who forged Zeus' thunderbolts, Poseidon's trident, and Hades' helm of invisibility. In later traditions, Cyclopes served as blacksmiths for Hephaestus, working in forges beneath volcanoes. Their single eye may have originated from ancient misinterpretation of dwarf elephant skulls, whose large nasal cavity resembles an eye socket.

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Greek mythology. Possible origins in misidentification of dwarf elephant skulls (nasal cavity resembles single eye socket).
origins.folklore_connections: Giants, one-eyed beings in various cultures, forge gods and volcanoes.

Paleontologist suggests dwarf elephant skulls inspired Cyclops myth

history.modern_era: Cyclopes remain iconic one-eyed giants in Western culture. The Polyphemus story is a classic tale of cunning defeating brute strength. Modern interpretations explore themes of civilization vs. barbarism and the power of intelligence.

polyphemus.location: Cave on an island (later identified as Sicily)
polyphemus.story: Trapped Odysseus and crew in cave, ate several men. Odysseus got him drunk, blinded him with heated stake while calling himself 'Nobody.' When other Cyclopes asked who hurt him, Polyphemus said 'Nobody,' so they didn't help. Odysseus escaped by clinging to underside of sheep.
polyphemus.curse: Called on father Poseidon to curse Odysseus' voyage home

brontes.role: Divine blacksmith who forged Zeus' thunderbolts
brontes.significance: One of the three original Cyclopes

dwarf_elephant_theory.description: Paleontologist Othenio Abel (1914) proposed that ancient Greeks finding dwarf elephant skulls could have misinterpreted the large nasal cavity as a single eye socket
dwarf_elephant_theory.evidence: Dwarf elephant skulls found in Mediterranean caves; large central nasal cavity
dwarf_elephant_theory.credibility: Widely discussed theory, though not definitively proven

traditions: Odysseus and the triumph of cunning
